results.title: Joey: the autobiography of Joey Deacon (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Gibson, Peter Goodchild and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Joey Deacon, born in 1920 with brain damage, grew up severely spastic, unable to talk or walk. When, in 1928, his mother died, he was sent to an institution where he lived for years, quite unable to make himself understood. Then, in 1941, he met Ernie Roberts who had one remarkable skill - he could understand Joey. This led to a new and richer life, and this film tells Joey’s remarkable story. Based on Joey Deacon’s book “Tongue tied”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Gibson, Peter Goodchild and British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: China: times of silk and gold (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Professor William Watson, Professor of Chinese Art and Archaeology at the University of London, and Magnus Magnusson continue their journey across modern China, visiting one of the world’s great Buddhist shrines; the caves at Lyang; Sian, the ancient capital; and the tomb of a T’ang princess who died in 701 AD In the Forbidden City of Kubblah Khan in Peking, a remarkable clock is discovered - a present to the Emperor from Britain’s first trade mission in the 18th century.

results.title: Birth (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Part five of the series, “The Family of Man” which sets out to compare family life in five different locations around the world. In this programme, pregnancy, birth and attitudes of women in all five places are examined, with a side-long look at different superstitions which reveal some strange stories. The programme asks, “Do women in peasant countries give birth with less pain and effort? And if so, why?”

results.title: Steps of Sturt
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Jack Absalom’s outback Australia series”.
From his home at Broken Hill, Jack Absalom retraces the journey of the English explorer Charles Sturt who was convinced the centre of Australia contained a vast inland sea. Sturt’s journey was one of great hardship as his party was drought bound for over six months at one location, ravaged by scurvy and attacked by wild Aborigines on whose waters the party had camped. The story tells of the gold rush following Sturt’s explorations, of the perils still to be encountered and some novel direction finding techniques.

results.title: In Grave danger of falling food/barefoot economist
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visionaries”.
In Grave Danger of Falling Food - Bill Mollison believes that the most destructive force on the planet is modern agriculture. It destroys our soils, poisons our water and produces toxic food. Instead, he has designed Permaculture, a system that uses the engineering principles of nature itself. He combines hundreds of plants and animals into a fertile self-regulating ecosystem. “Barefoot Economist” - Manfred Max-Neef is a Chilean economist trying to address the problems of Latin America. He thinks the worst solutions are those imposed from the top by financial planners, and the best are those worked out on the ground by local communities.

results.title: Long Shadows the Legacy of the American Civil War
results.brief_description: A documentary examining the legacy of the American Civil War and its effect upon the politics and people of the south in the 1980s. Interviews with Robert Penn Warren, Studs Terkel, Jimmy Carter and others.

results.title: Raiders of the top end
results.brief_description: A factual and exclusive account of the mainland activities of Exercise Kangaroo 89 which tested the ability of the Australian Defence Force to operate in and defend against terrorist style attack the vast, remote and sparsely populated region of Australia’s Top End. The program graphically captures the reality of how the threats and attacks by effective Kumarian enemy raiding parties were dealt with. It won a gold camera award and a certificate of creative excellence at the USA Film and Video Festival in Chicago 1990.

results.title: The Last horizon
results.creator_credit: Robert Raymond, Anthony Buckley and Quantum Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Man on the rim series”.
Part 4: “The Feathered Serpent” - The Olmec, Toltec, Maya and Aztec cultures represent the highest achievement of American Indian society. This episode shows how these complex communities and their skills in architecture, sculpture and the arts. “The Last Horizon” The final episode in the greatest migratory movement in the history of the human race belongs to the Polynesians. Their epic voyages from Fiji and Tonga carried them to Hawaii, Tahiti, New Zealand and Easter Island. New sails appeared on the horizon from Europe breaking the isolation of the Pacific. Now, there is a new dawning of the Pacific Century.

results.title: Stopping the coming ice age
results.brief_description: Probably the most important video many of us will ever see. Record cold winters and record summer heat and drought, increasing floods, hurricanes and tornadoes, dying forests, massive fuel burning and the clearcutting of the tropical rainforests are all related. The next Ice Age may be virtually upon us, a natural 100,000 year cycle driven by erosion, the death and rebirth of forests and the rise and fall of greenhouse gases. It has already resulted in massive starvation. If we act quickly we may be able to stop it, if not we may be eating less in seven years.

results.title: Bangkok - the City of Angels/the Kingdom of Thailand
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Colin Baker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Bangkok: The City of Angels - Bangkok, capital of the Kingdom of Thailand is one of Asia’s most popular destinations. Enjoy the breathtaking Royal Palace, the ornate Royal Barges and Bangkok’s beautiful temples, the magic of the Viman Mek Teak Palace - “The Castle in the Clouds”, the world’s largest golden teak structure, the bustle of the Floating Markets, the ancient capital of Atyutthaya, the beautiful River Kwai (with its famous bridge), visit the Rose Garden and enjoy its exuberant and lavish stage presentation, complete with elephant show. Bangkok is famous for its food and shopping, contrast the tempo and excitement of modern day Bangkok, with the tranquil splendour of the Ancient City. “The Kingdom of Thailand” - Siam, as it was once known, with its delightful people, offers the traveller unlimited attractions - the fun and sun of Pattaya, the beauty of Chiang Mai, “Thailand’s Northern Shangri-la” with visits to the Hill Tribes and elephant camps, visit Chiang Rai and the famed Golden Triangle and join the wedding celebrations of a remote Hill tribe. Rated: G
